Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Harold Williams is "Algebras, Integrable Systems, and Quivers with Potential." The host institution for the fellowship is University of Texas at Austin, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Andrew Neitzke.

Performance_Institution.Name: The University of Texas at Austin

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project advanced a range of new ideas in pure mathematics and its connections to theoretical physics. A central role in the supported research is played by the concept of a cluster algebra, a recently discovered class of mathematical structures which have been the subject of intense study over the past two decades. One of the most interesting features of cluster algebras is the diverse range of areas of mathematics in which they appear. Because of this, cluster algebras have helped reveal many mysterious and previously undiscovered connections between different fields within mathematics. By understanding these new connections, we are able to obtain a fuller and deeper understanding of mathematics as a whole. 

One important aspect of this area is that it touches on the border between mathematics and physics. Part of the PI's work expands a growing dictionary between these two fields. On the side of physics, this involves the study of quantum field theories, a class of physical models used to describe our universe at very small scales. On the side of mathematics, this involves algebraic geometry, the modern study of solutions to polynomial equations. The PI's work expands this dictionary by showing that the physical theory of so-called Wilson-'t Hooft line operators can be described by the algebro-geometric theory of so-called perverse coherent sheaves (which the PI in turn shows can be effectively studied using the theory of cluster algebras). This new connection opens the door to transferring ideas and insights between physics and mathematics in a way that is sure to benefit both subjects.
